Journal.Title: The journal of physical chemistry. A

Article.ArticleTitle: Laboratory Studies of Vibrational Excitation in O<sub>2</sub>( a<sup>1</sup>Δ<sub>g</sub>, v) Involving O<sub>2</sub>, N<sub>2</sub>, and CO<sub>2</sub>.

AbstractText: Collisional removal of electronic energy from O<sub>2</sub> in the low-lying a<sup>1</sup>Δ<sub>g</sub> state is typically an extremely slow process for the v = 0 level. In this study, we report results on the deactivation of O<sub>2</sub>( a<sup>1</sup>Δ<sub>g</sub>, v = 1-3) in collisions with O<sub>2</sub> and CO<sub>2</sub>. Ozone photodissociation in the 200-310 nm Hartley band is the source of O<sub>2</sub>( a, v), and resonance-enhanced multiphoton ionization is used to probe the vibrational-level populations. Deactivation of the a( v = 1-3) levels in collisions with O<sub>2</sub> at 300 K is fast, with rate coefficients of (5.6 ± 1.1) × 10<sup>-11</sup>, (3.6 ± 0.4) × 10<sup>-11</sup>, and (1.9 ± 0.4) × 10<sup>-11</sup> cm<sup>3</sup> s<sup>-1</sup> (2σ) for v = 1, 2, and 3, respectively. The relaxation process appears to involve a near-resonant electronic energy transfer pathway analogous to that observed in vibrationally excited O<sub>2</sub>( b<sup>1</sup>Σ<sub>g</sub><sup>+</sup>). With CO<sub>2</sub> collider gas, the removal rate coefficient at 300 K is (1.8 ± 0.4) × 10<sup>-14</sup> and (4.4 ± 0.6) × 10<sup>-14</sup> cm<sup>3</sup> s<sup>-1</sup> (2σ) for v = 1 and 2, respectively. Despite the small mole fraction of O<sub>2</sub> in the atmospheres of Mars and Venus, O<sub>2</sub> is at least as important as CO<sub>2</sub> in the final stages of collisional relaxation within the O<sub>2</sub> vibrational-level manifold.
